ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Ann is a fantastic professor. I am incredibly sorry that the school has decided to let her go. I will be a major loss.
My only comment is a HUGE thank you to Ann! Keep teaching this class--it is such a necessary and enjoyable one for anyone wanting to work in any capacity with the environment!!
The field trip was scheduled at a time when MESc students had to participate in the masters colloquium.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The field trip to the New Jersey Pine Barrens. It was very well done and I learned a huge amount.
Individual assignments (presentations).

The best parts of this course were Ann's knowledge of and enthusiasm for the materials. I also really enjoyed and appreciated the guest lecture from Matt Carroll, I thought his contributions were thought-provoking and right on point and I think he's a great addition to the course if you can bring him back next year.
It's real, and based in science. The lectures are good, and student presentations are phenomenal.

I very much enjoyed the group discussions following the student presentations. I think that opportunities for student communication are extremely important for learning because of the exposure to new ideas and because I retain information better when I have something invested in it. I also really appreciated the pacing of the work and the total workload. It allowed me to delve deeply into issues and topics that were of particular interest to me without bogging down in general or irrelevant information.

I enjoyed the lectures, and Ann's lectures, as always, were clear and organized. I also like the student presentations, which provided an opportunity to get a more in-depth perspective on a specific issue.
Ann gave a great overview of the science and policy. From that foundation, students gave excellent presentations. I learned so much from Ann and other students.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I wonder if we could have made the final presentations shorter and fit three into each session. Then we could have had a couple of extra class sessions to discuss the policy and cultural dimensions of fires and fire fighting in the U.S. (and other places!) in a little more depth. I also wish we had all been able to read one of the books--The Big Burn or Young Men and Fire (or another one)--and had a half-day class discussion about them.
The course is too slow. Maybe just make it a 2 credit course? There doesn't seem to be enough material, even with the student presentations.
Student presentation dates should be agreed upon well in advance of the presentation.

A little more discussion of the readings. There was a lot of information in the readings that could be discussed. Also, the timing of the field trip was unfortunate, most people could not go due to conflicts.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Rather than how it fits into my overall program, I'd like to state that it fits into my overall future plans to work in the mountain west. Fire is a native aspect to this landscape (and many others) so a firm understanding of this topic is going to be very helpful.

It was a great fit with my western focus, and helped me to gain a deeper understanding of the ecology of specific ecosystems. It's also wonderfully interdisciplinary since it deals with science, policy, economics, and management.

As a western-oriented forester, this course is critical in terms of understanding a central aspect of western landscapes. Getting an overview of how fire has shaped and continues to shape policy and management is essential for anyone hoping to work in land management in the West.

This course was my first real exposure to fire issues. Unfortunately, I feel as though the class was a standalone course since few if any other forestry courses really focus on western silviculture/operations. It's a good course for someone wanting to work in the eastern US who wants exposure to western issues. I feel that it's not enough to prepare someone for actually working in the west.
This was an important aspect of my program because I am interested in western forestry issues. The ecological and social aspects of wildfire are incredibly important to my studies at FES.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Similar to my answer above, because I will be living and working in a fire adapted landscape in my future.
Great professor and it fit well into my overall focus here at FES .
I took this course to gain a better understanding of fire as a management tool because I foresee needing to work with prescribed burns in my career.
It is important for my course of study.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes
Yes, they exceeded my expectations! Thank you, Ann, for a phenomenal semester.
For the most part. I would have liked a little bit more depth.
yes!
Yes

Yes, I feel like I got a very good overview of all aspects of fire science and policy. It would be easy to make the course too narrow. This course had the correct amount of breadth to understand how to manage fires.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I don't think this course is going to be offered next year...
Take it, and really dig into your project at the end of the term. Use it as an excuse to call / email people and build your network.
Take it.
Take it!

This course is useful for students who already have a good understanding of the social issues around fire but want a bit more background on the technical, scientific parts of fire. I learned the most from those lectures. Students who are very new to fire issues may have a hard tim participating in class discussions.
Take it! There is a lot to learn here. Take discussion and presentation times seriously so you can really learn from fellow students.
